title: For what value of 'k' are these two equations not inconsitent: 2x + 3y = 5; 6x + 9y = k? - Quora
tags: Middle and High School Math Homework Question

response.answer_text: K = 15 First of all check,What are the conditions for a linear equation of two variables to be inconsistent?Inconsistent means that you have no solution in x and y for the given two equations. For the 2 equations linear equation of two variables to be inconsistent, their graph must be parallel, but not coincident.Coincident means having same graph. Now, when will their graph be coincident, when two equations signify same line. First equation is 2x + 3y =5Next equation is 6x + 9y = kHere, a2/a1 = 3b1/b2 = 3 c2/c1 = k/5 Here comes the simple rule of checking consistency of linear equation which is given in NCERT BOOK OF CLASS 10, 1. When a2/a1 = b1/b2 = c2/c1, the equations are consistent 2.When a2/a1 = b1/b2 not equal to c2/c1, the equations are inconsistent. So, for equations to be not inconsistent or consistent, we must have  a2/a1 = b2/b1 = c2/c1=> k/5 =3 Therefore, K =15. Hence, For K = 15, the equations are not inconsistent and rest for all K, they are inconsistent. Hope that helps. :)

The above equations will be in consistent state for k=15.Because 2x+3y=5 and 6x+9y=15 will form parallel lines.You can also get the same result by forming an augmented matrix and then reduce it to row echelon form.In case you are not aware about this method, it is easily visible for these two equations you will get multiple solutions of values x and y. Such as (0,5/3) , (1,1) etc.So the system is in consistent state for k=15 and gives infinitely many solutions for the same.For any value of k where k is not 15, it is in inconsistent state.Hope this answers your question.

15.A system of equations can only be not inconsistent i.e consistent if it :-1.has infinite set of solutions2.has a unique set of solutions. The second  option is ruled out as the ratio of coefficients is equal for the two variables.

K=15System of equations is inconsistent if there are no values of the variables x,y that satisfies the equation. For the given system we notice that one equation is the scalar multiple of the other. Hence the geometric interpretation would suggest that not only are the lines parallel, but that they are collinear. Cheers :)
k=15 because if you multiply the equation 2x+3y=5 by 3, you will get 6x+9y=15. 6x+9y-k=6x+9y-15. -k=-15. k=15.

Multiply the second equation by 1/32x+3y=k/3 Now since both equations have the term 2x+3y on one side, we can set them equal to each other.  k/3=5Multiply both sides by 3 k=15 And it is for this value of k that these two equations will give the same graph.
for k = 15, both equations will eventually be same and hence will be consistent, having infinitely many solutions
For k = 10 the two equations will represent the same line, and there will be no point of intersection of the two lines.
